intro: Micromeria cristata subsp. carminea, commonly known as the carmine flaxflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is a member of the citrus family, Rutaceae, and is characterized by its small, fragrant flowers and narrow, linear leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to dry climates. Its flowers, which range in color from pink to deep red, bloom in spring and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The subspecies is distinguished by its vibrant floral coloration and compact growth habit.
